ITV has suspended The Jeremy Kyle show after a guest died shortly after filming, and is conducting a review into the episode "given the seriousness of this event".

The broadcaster took Monday's show off air and replaced it with a repeat of Dickinson's Real Deal.

The participant from the episode died a week after recording it.

ITV said everyone at the show is "shocked and saddened" and "thoughts are with the family and friends".

BornCynic I was looking round the web to see what happened to Bob Mackenzie's lawsuit against the AA and have come up with nothing. Anyone have any links / information please?
JP11:20am

Here's UBS:

Soundbuy Greggs on a roll..........
JP11:20am

VOD has cut its dividend by -40% to €0.09 (from €0.1507). Confirmation of a cut will likely lead to an initial negative reaction, but it will not be a complete surprise given press reports (link) and the -5% move in the share price yesterday. We think the dividend cut is the right thing to do – there was little credit being given for the prior dividend (10% yield), it removes an overhang from the company and accelerates de-leveraging (-0.3x over three years vs 2.9x currently). Alongside the announced divestment of New Zealand for €2.1bn, pro-forma leverage will be at the bottom-end of the 2.5-3.0x guidance range medium-term. The new dividend represents a 5.9% 2019E dividend yield vs 5% for the sector and we estimate the dividend will represent c60% of EFCF after normalised spectrum costs with a progressive policy going forward.

11:20 am
JP11:20am

Q4 in-line – declines starting to bottom out?
Q4 was broadly in-line with -0.6% service revenue growth (vs cons -0.7% after +0.1% in Q3) and EBITDA +3.1% organically to €14,139m (cons €14,135m) and FY EFCF at €5,443m (cons €5,311m). While Italy and Spain were weaker q-o-q, underlying trends appear to be improving into Q1-20. Germany was resilient and Vodacom is stabilising.

JP11:21am

FY-20 guidance – higher IFRS15/16 impact / expect a gradual recovery
VOD has guided towards ‘low single-digit’ organic growth to give EBITDA of €13.8-14.2bn (cons +2-3% to €14.135bn) underpinned by cost savings with EFCF of €5.4bn (cons €5.131bn). The mid-point of EBITDA guidance (€14.0bn) would imply consensus EBITDA needs to be trimmed marginally but this reflects higher non-cash impacts from IFRS15/16 (-€400m vs cons -€300m). EFCF guidance is ahead, partly benefiting from factoring of handset receivables (€200m benefit for both FY-19/20). For Q1-20, we expect organic service revenue trends to be similar to the -0.6% in Q4-19 with a gradual improvement thereafter. EBITDA growth should accelerate in H2-20 given an easier comparable, cost savings and the dropping out of football costs in Spain.

JP11:21am

Valuation: PT based on SOTP/DCF
The stock offers a 13% calendarised EFCF yield in 2019E (or 4.5% in 2019E post spectrum rising to 10% in 2020E). We see the stock as too cheap but investors may want more visibility that operating trends are past the worst before re-rating the stock.

JP11:23am

Reminder: Vodafone is the midst of a plan to shift non-core assets, buy Libert Global's German and E European cable assets and wade into 5G. All of this costs cash. So maintaining the tricky balance between investment and ebitda/ net debt is crucial.

JP11:24am

Here's Jefferies:

JP11:24am

A 40% DPS cut was the min needed to relieve leverage concerns. Mgmt must now convince that VOD is capable of returning to growth to support the progressive divi policy. 4Q18/19 no longer seen as low-point for SR decline; trends now to recover by 2H19/20. And with guidance in-line vs cons (ex-one-offs), growth prospects remain unconvincing. No new invt program but CEO comment that funding headroom will support goals suggests higher capital intensity on the way.

11:24 am
JP11:24am

New FY19/20 guidance is on an IFRS15/16 basis excl LBTY German/CEE assets but incl NZ disposal (announced last night). EBITDA guided to €13.8bn-14.2bn (cons: €14.1bn). Adjusted for interest recharges (now seen €100m higher), cons would be €14.0bn. FCF (pre spectrum) guided to 'at least' €5.4bn (cons: €5.1bn). Adjusted for €200m benefit from factoring handset receivables, cons would be €5.3 In our downgrade report, Vodafone - No Silver Bullet (8 Oct 2018), we identified a 40% DPS cut as a minimum necessary to relieve immediate leverage concerns. Today's DPS cut is justified by rev pressure and higher German auction outlay, both factors largely outside VOD mgmt control. Now aiming to reduce leverage by 0.3x over 3Y reaching low-end of 2.5-3.0x in next few years. We understand that LTIP targets unchanged on a LFL perimeter basis. There is no new invt program announced today but, with mgmt asserting that funding headroom will support its transformation goals and a return to growth necessary to support the new progressive dividend policy, we believe that a decision on raising capital intensity may only have been deferred.

Tom Dalgleish 5G doesnt seem the bonanza some predict in telcos
JP11:25am

And to round things off -- one of the best on the sector, Neil Campling of Mirabaud:

JP11:25am

After the negative reports in the weekend press the headline Vodafone Q4 and FY19 results are better than feared and the dividend cut is less than expected. The dividend cut of 40% is slightly less than the 50%-60% we think investors expected and it’s a proactive decision - with the need to balance the costs of 5G auctions, invest in 5G networks for long term growth opportunities and delever the balance sheet. The FY results have been achieved with 3.1% EBITDA growth (3% guided) and FCF of €5.5B, slightly above expectations of €5.4B, so there are signs of (small) progress – or at least things aren’t getting worse. On an operating basis there was good commercial performance in Spain and record low contract churn in Europe. Guidance for FY20 EBITDA is a range of €13.8 to €14.2B (with consensus bang in line at the mid-point €14B), implying low single digit organic growth.

Vodafone 5G will go live in seven cities in the UK on 3rd July this year. How they price this service is the key to the success or otherwise of the opportunity. 5G needs to be priced higher than current services to make financial sense – and they need to sell to consumers the benefits of the super-fast speeds rather than merely ‘nice to have’ upgrades. The example in South Korea, where one carrier broke ranks and instigated a price war, serves as a reminder of the risks in the sector.

11:25 am
JP11:25am

The company is focused on cost-cutting, FCF generation, asset sales of non-core markets and a disciplined 5G strategy which will see a number of network sharing and co-operation deals with other carriers. The Liberty Global M&A deal remains as a key catalyst and investors want to see ongoing improvements in FCF, driven by the combination of stepped-up cost cutting and capital spending discipline. Vodafone’s equity free cash flow yield is now 16%, one of the highest in the telco sector – reflecting low expectations among investors. Getting the 5G strategy right is key to the future of the company (as it is for all the telco operators). With European telecom operators the problems are simple – regulation is onerous, the number of operators in Europe are too numerous, the returns have been regulated away over the last decade or more. On this last point, just look at Vodafone’s returns; the company has gone from enjoying a 27% ROCE (return on capital employed) peak in 2006 to just 4% in 2018 (see chart below). How they can improve from here will only be possible with consolidation being allowed in the sector, by focusing on growth capex investments and by enjoying pricing power for the first time in more than a decade. Much of this depends on sector based decisions; on MNOs looking to extract higher prices from customers and pitching higher service level offerings rather than the focus of subscriber growth at any cost mentality of the past. There are signs of progress in parts of Europe – but where there are new entrants to the market (1&1 Drillisch in Germany for example) then the age old risks remain - new operators can only reach scale by attracting new subscribers – and the easiest way to do this is to undercut existing operators and use price as a weapon.

JP11:26am

Neil prefers the tower companies. The old sell pick-axes during a gold rush thesis:

JP11:26am

We continue to prefer investments in the telecom complex to focus on the Tower companies rather than the telecom operators. Cellnex remains our top pick in Europe. We think Cellnex has the potential to become the industrial scale tower company in Europe and a partner of choice for the European MNO’s who will need to ramp 5G investment and footprint from 2020-2022.

The economic reasons for mobile operators to spin off their tower assets comes as the shift of tower business economics shift from growth to operational excellence – specialist providers of network services with operational skills in energy management, operations, low-cost design and customized site planning/real-estate. The economic attractions in 5G could accelerate as operators could look to unlock value from their tower assets and redeploy towards growth capex.

New spectrum bands (mmWave, C-band, CBRS in the U.S. for example) will add to the long term network solution of increasing data traffic to increase networks’ physical capacities. The tower operators’ attraction is simple. Offer the wireless service providers a potentially cheaper alternative to building a new tower site: co-locating equipment on an existing site that is share with other wireless service providers and operated by the tower company.

Europe has been slow to follow this shift relative to the US and Asia but there are signs of increased activity. The ratio of towerco penetration varies considerably by country, and it is conceivable that countries with low penetration rates could follow the path of the U.S. (over 80% independent) or India 71%. In China this towerco penetration is 100%. In Australia Telstra, the operator which owns the majority of the country’s towers (approximately 8,000) has decided to carve out all of its non-mobile related assets including data centres, fibre, copper, subsea cable and poles into a separate infrastructure company. Towercos own 64% of Malaysia’s towers, 45% of Sri Lanka’s towers and 26% of the towers in Thailand.

https://www.greggs...vegan-sausage-roll

11:34 am
JP11:34am

@Soundbuy -- let's not go there.

JP11:34am

Here's Peel Hunt:

JP11:34am

Greggs’ exceptional recent LFL (12-13% over the last two months) is a function of better execution, strong range evolution and an impressive surfing of the vegan sausage roll wave. Even management is surprised by the strength of recent trade, which comes at a time when, in general, High Street footfall has been a bit iffy. We are upgrading today by 6-8%, assuming that the glorious LFL doesn’t persist. And therein lies the rub. We’d put our hands up and admit that HOLD has been the wrong recommendation here but we might just be reaching “peak Greggs” and it is always difficult for shares to go up into slowing LFL. If someone can quickly invent the next “vegan sausage roll” equivalent then maybe the multiple can go forward, but we think it’s unlikely. Answers on a postcard...

11:34 am
JP11:35am

An acceleration through March/April: The Cheshire Cat impressions from management at the Prelims in early March suggested that not only had LFL started with a bang (up 9.6% for the first 7 weeks of FY19), but that profitability was ahead too. For things to get even better is a very impressive endorsement of what Greggs is up to right now. The implied LFL for the last 12 weeks has been 12-13%. Admittedly the comp isn’t the toughest, but most retailers have been bemoaning the lack of footfall to High Streets and shopping centres, so for things to accelerate through Easter is impressive. Especially so when unseasonally warm weather usually means a switch out of pasties and own made products into cold drinks etc., as seen last Summer. The improvements to the range have all contributed as Greggs has essentially lengthened its day by enhancing its breakfast/coffee offer and building trade later on with a pizza and drink deal. It would, however, be wrong not to single out the vegan sausage roll for particular talisman praise. In January/February, demand outstripped supply, creating a somewhat mystical feel around the product, not to mention a tonne of publicity. Now fully available in all stores, new shoppers have been drawn into Greggs and they’ve been encouraged to try the others ranges too.

JP11:35am

Operational gearing works: Sometimes when there is “surprise” demand, it doesn’t quite drop through to be bottom line, as companies would like, but not a bit of that here. Cost ratios are stable and interestingly there are two plusses on the gross margin side. Firstly, at the heart of the demand has been Greggs’ own-made products (clearly good news), and the strong sales number is also positive for waste numbers. We could have gone further with our upgrade but we’ll go from £102m to £110m this year, assuming 5% LFL in H2, then £109m goes to £115m and for £114m read £120m. By 2021 Greggs will be pushing 100p of EPS.

Soundbuy .......noted
JP11:35am

Peak Greggs?: We’ve missed the run by being too nervous about the valuation. Today’s update is undoubtedly first class but can Greggs keep it up? Is sales momentum likely to persist? 5% LFL in H2 would actually be a good effort, but will the forecast and the shares press on if that’s what Greggs prints? We’d say not, given that the multiple is nearly 20x. Great company but HOLD.

Back to Greggs, here's UBS:

1966AndAllThat It's surprising jcdecaux are not more involved with the rollout of G5 masts considering their access to council infrastructure such as street lights
JP11:42am

Early AGM statements reports continuation of strong trading trend
Greggs have reported LFL growth +11.1% for the first 19 weeks of 2019 vs. 9.6% LFL reported for the first 7 weeks of the year. Whilst the further strengthening of trading in part reflects weak comps after poor weather in March and April last year (c.1% of YTD LFL from Beast from the East), it mainly implies a strong underlying trading trend, with LFL still running at c.+9% against strengthening comparatives. Management now expect underlying profits to be 'materially higher than previous expectations', and we increase our 2019E EPS forecasts by +12%, 2020 + 18% and 2021 +17% to reflect this.

JP11:42am

Update to forecasts: PBT inc IFRS 16 adjustment now at £113m
The strong current rate of trading which is transaction volume driven means we now expect 7.5% LFL growth for 2019 vs. 5% previously, which implies a c.6% LFL growth for the remained of 2019. This increases our EBIT forecast to £119m, +11% ahead, and PBT to £113m including the adjustment for IFRS 16 which reduced PBT by c.£4.2m in 2019, accounting for planning increased investment in strategic initiatives.

11:42 am
JP11:42am

Potential to accelerate strategic initiatives
With a material upgrade to profit expectations for the year, Greggs are also using the opportunity to accelerate strategic initiatives which should further increase the runway for growth going forward. Initiatives include the extending of shop opening hours into the evening (which typically provides a short term drag to profits as trade builds), and other digital and marketing initiatives.

JP11:42am

Valuation: DCF based valuation, increase from 1725p to 1880p
Our DCF based price target rises +9% to 1880p reflecting increases in near-term forecasts. We maintain our assumptions of an 8.5% WACC and 2.5% long-term growth rate.

To roll up the Greggs coverage, here's Shore Capital Markets:

11:46 am
JP11:46am

Greggs has issued another surprise trading update, reporting total sales for the 19 weeks to 11 May 2019 up 15.1% including LFL growth in company managed shops of 11.1%.

The growth represents an acceleration from the already strong start to the year, suggesting LFL trading over the past 12 weeks of c12% - stunning it must be said. Growth is said to have been underpinned by the roll-out of vegan-friendly sausage rolls to all shops, though other categories are said to have shown “good growth” reflecting investment in range and quality in recent years.

38 new shops have been opened in the period (including 10 franchised units in transport locations), with 22 shops closed taking the total number of units to 1,969 (1,700 company-managed shops and 269 franchised units).

JP11:47am

Investment in the Group’s new manufacturing platforms is progressing in line with plan and construction of the new distribution centre at Amesbury has now commenced. We are encouraged that the roll-out of SAP to payroll and manufacturing has progressed successfully, with further roll-out to come in the months ahead.

Whilst comparatives toughen over the remainder of the year management “now anticipate materially higher sales for the 2019 year as a whole” than previously expecting, and with cost inflation expected to be broadly in line with original plan guidance is for underlying profits (before exceptional costs) to be materially higher than previous expectations.

We place our FY2019 CPTP forecast of £102m under-review ahead of speaking to management, though continue to question how long such strong LFL growth can be sustained and more importantly how many more stores can be opened over the medium term beyond the current c2k. It is this medium term constraint that holds us back from being more positive, noting the pre-upgrade PER of 22.6x and EV/EBITDA multiple of 11.3 (which would fall to 20.6x and 10.6x respectively on a 10% upgrade – long term growth multiples in our view).

We reiterate our HOLD recommendation, though fully expect the shares to trade strongly this morning.

JP11:52am

Q1 update this morning. As I know nothing about the business, here's UBS:

11:52 am
JP11:53am

Q: How did results compare to expectations?

A: Beat on revenue and operating EBITDA. Q119 group rev grew +21% to €149m (+15% organic), +3% ahead of UBS (€145m) driven by AS24 and Consumer Services. Group ordinary operating EBITDA grew +11% to €71m (organic +15%) above UBSe €69m driven by AS24. Q119 adj. net income grew +17% to €41m (UBS in line). Net debt in Mar-19 was €691m with leverage of 2.4x vs 2.6x in Dec-18.

JP11:53am

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?

A: IS24 revenues grew +8% yoy to €65m (UBS broadly in line) with EBITDA +8% to €43m (UBS in line) and margins up +30bps. Within IS24, residential revenue grew by a double digit rate (UBS +9%) driven by VIA and higher agent numbers. Business revenue also grew double digit (UBS in line). VIA revenues (product) grew +17% yoy to €20.7m. AS24 rev grew +17% yoy to €45m (UBS €43m) driven by ARPU growth with dealers in Germany slightly down vs Dec-18 and dealers in European Core Countries stable. EBITDA grew +43% to €25m (UBS €22m) with margins up by 10p.p to 54.8%. Consumer Services rev grew +59% yoy to €39m (UBS €37m) and organic revenue growth was +19%. EBITDA fell -39% to €5m (UBS €6m) driven by Finanzcheck losses.

JP11:53am

Q: Has the company's outlook / guidance changed?

A: Guidance confirmed. Scout24 expects FY19 group reported rev to grow +15-17% (UBSe +13%) and EBITDA margins of 52-54% (UBSe +51.8%) with non-operating costs of €25-27m (UBSe €27m). For IS24, Scout24 expects reported rev growth of +8-10% (UBSe +6%) and EBITDA margins of 70% (UBSe 69.5%). Scout24 expects AS24 reported rev growth now in the upper-end range of +9-11% (UBSe +9%) and EBITDA margins of 54% (UBSe 54%); Consumer Services reported rev growth of high 30s-low 40s (UBS 42%) with EBITDA margins of 30% (UBSe 23%). UBSe below guidance given we assume Bestellerprinzip is introduced in H219.

Q: How would we expect investors to reach?

A: Strong results with solid VIA revenue growth, strong operating leverage at AS24. AS24 guidance lifted to upend end. We see upside risk to FY19 forecasts.
